forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> I would assume they are DOS bootable disks with their own basic gui..as They perform a very specific function that requires no interference..Updating system board firmware, configuring RAID arrays...However, I cant be certain as they launch into their own GUI as soon as they launch

Well, you have two choices right now:  
1) tell us what these "secret" .iso's are (if they are not proprietary/Commercial), or, better even, mount the .iso with any "virtual CD software", such as IMDISK or VirtualCloneDrive.  
Say that you mount them as drive "X:"  
open a command prompt and run in it:  

```
DIR  X: /S>C:\1stiso.dir
```

mount the other .iso as X: and rune  

```
DIR  X: /S>C:\2ndiso.dir
```

Compress C:\\1stiso.dir and C:\\2ndiso.dir in a .zip or .7z archive and attach it to your next post.  

This way we have a way to understand on what they are based  

2) try "blindly" the proposed mapping to (hd32) with grub4dos, after having read the whereto and the guide:  
[http://www.boot-land...hp?showtopic=14](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=14 "External link")  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=5187](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=5187 "External link")  

If 2) works, your problem is solved. ![:poke:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/poke.gif)  

If it doesn't work, you'll need to choose 1) anyway.  

jaclaz
